Note: This is a review of someone who has played the game back in 2008 for months, and decided to check the game out almost 10 years later on it's steam debut.Cons: - Pay2Win. They literally sell gold (alz) in the cash shop, aswell as enchantments and pretty much every ingame item is buyable with real money.- High cash shop prices. Is this 2008? It's bad enough that it's a p2w game, but "premium" costs 13$! (same as WoW), costumes 23$. Yep, if you want to look like a cowboy or a schoolgirl that'll be 23$.- Very Grindy. Korean mmo. You like those "kill 290 monsters" quests? And grinding millions of monsters to get to max level? Well this is the perfect game for you. To give you an idea, to get a must-have character ability called "Battle Mode 3" you'll need to kill 290 monsters per quest, and you'll have to do it 30 times, that's 8700 monsters you have to kill to get the ability.-No hablo inglés. This is Cabal North America, but don't expect to see any american or english speakers. This community is made up of 90% brazilians and latinos who have no idea of how to speak english.-Bad Community. Besides the language, everyone seems to have almost 10 years of experience in the game, as well as playing in multiple servers at the same time. This wasn't that bad if they were helpful, but everyone has no patience and just wants to grind till max level and steal your drops.-Bad Support. There's only one person in charge of CABAL Steam forums, and he/she only gets around 5 threads per day asking for help, and they still get all unanswered. I've also had an issue for the past 2 weeks, which i contacted support with every information, pictures, and everything they could possibly need, and they didn't do anything.-Armor class. Every armor is class locked now. No more heavy bladers or heavy mages, you have to wear what's meant for your class now. This cuts alot of what you could do with stat customization.-Dungeons make no sense. To progress in a dungeon you have to do quests, and they consist of "Talk to this bookshelf" "Now go back and talk to this statue" "Now go and talk to a lamp".-Different client languages. They have an english and spanish client, which is awesome. The problem is that it is not client based, but server. This means that if someone links a [CRITICAL RING +2] in the chat with a spanish client you'll see [ANILLO DEL ATAQUE CRITICO +2] even if you're playing with the english client. Same thing for the class names, if someone posts something like "Need AA  for dungeon last spot!!", you have to guess that AA is "Arqueiro Arcano" which is Spanish for FA "Force Archer". Pros:- No more 42 minutes maze dungeons in the story quests.- Quests now give skill exp, no need to leave your character in the training dummies.- Skills are grouped in "attack skill" now. No more Attack/magic separation, and grindind those 2 to transcender.- Good leveling up event. You get free premium, free boosters and free items. If you level at a good pace you have everything to enjoy all the good things that the game has to offer.-The graphics are still pretty. The skill effects are still up to the best in almost any mmo.-Combo mode. This game is known for the combo mode, and It's still fun and challenging as it was years ago.-Amazing soundtrack. It goes from chill music in the cities, to hard rock in action zones, it's awesome.-GM's appear quite often. They usually show up, announce "GM buff channel9 BI", and you go and get a buff that increases HP and attack for an hour. -PVP mmo. You can basically PK or PVP anywhere, which is something that every mmo lacks nowadays. It even has a nice nation system between player factions (Capella vs Procyon), and a channel that allows you to kill people literally anywhere, even in the cities.-Frequent Events. So far. since it launched on steam, there is always an event going on.I do not recommend this game. Although I have put lots of hours in it, I can assure you it's just nostalgia and the level up event. As soon as the free boosters and items run out, It will be the end for me. The event will end on the 22nd of march, and if you didnt play and get to atleast level 150 by then, or if you're not thinking of spending hundreds of $ in Cabal, you'll be completely destroyed by the game.

												I played CABAL Online for about 3 months nonstop a couple of years ago. The only reason I stopped was I got back into WoW hardcore for a while. I kind of forgot about the game, so I'm excited to see it pop up on Steam. 


YouTube™ Video: Steam: CABAL Online  (no commentary) 

			Views: 863		

			Gameplay from the new Steam release of CABAL Online MMORPG. This is an older game that they just put onto Steam. It looks and feels old, but it's actually better than most modern MMOs, in my opinion.		

CABAL is not a new game, and you can definitely tell that right off the bat. But it doesn't play badly like some older MMOs do. You just have to deal with some kind of ugly outdated quest texts/fonts and some iffy (yet readable) translations. You can click to move if you want, or use WASD (or reassign keys to whatever you want). I don't care for the camera very much, honestly.The combat is pretty fun and low stress. The classes are about what you'd expect, your general MMO variety. They do play quite differently from eachother though- very unique. It's essentially a themepark with some neat mechanics. PVP is fun, but very DPS-focused (tanks and healers don't really play much of a role). Music is really weird for the genre, but it's pretty good. (It's like weird hard rock) There is a cash shop and premium and whatnot, but I wouldn't necessarily say it's p2w. It's DEFINITELY pay-to-advance-way-faster, though. but I think you can have a good time with CABAL for free.

												*My review is based on the first time I started playing this game.Ahhh, CABAL, my favorite MMORPG ever. (I have played a lot of MMORPG's) Where to begin, I started playing in 2009, with my first character being a Force Blader called ironman11. That character has been my main character to this date, it's level 166 now (also own all other classes, all around level 100-140). I have played the game a 1000+ hours, and know a lot about the game.What I like:- The skill system is a favorite of mine. You don't unlock skills as you level up as in most other games, you have to get Skill EXP to level your skill level up. Back in 2009 you could only get Skill EXP by 'skilling', that meant attacking a dummy for a hell of a long time while being AFK, and then coming back to see that your skill level has increased. One of the best feelings ever. After all those hours skilling, you could finally buy your fresh new skill of buff!Skilling is not required anymore since an update a while ago, you'll get Skill EXP with the quests.- Leveling. Yes, I liked it. Because you'd unlock new maps every 15 levels! Every time I unlocked a new map I was hyped! Back in the day leveling went EXTREMELY slow though, now you can quest/grind your way up to level 120 in about four days (I managed to do it, so I know it's possible.)- Graphics. Back in 2009, I thought the game looked awesome, for now the graphics are outdated and such, but they give me a nostalgic feel.- The soundtrack! The music in CABAL is beautiful in my opinion, for example, the beautiful theme of Bloody Ice, where you'd hang out to skillgrind or craft. I even listen to the OST outside of the game sometimes, again, to give me that nostalgic feel. :D- Dungeons. Everytime I entered a new dungeon for the first time, I watched a video before entering so that I knew the quest. Because all the dungeons have an objective, and to progress further into the dungeons need to kill mobs for items or click objects in a certain order etc.What I don't like:- Grind for Alz. Alz is the currency in CABAL Online, to get it you need to complete quests, but after level ~120 you don't get Alz anymore. The total amount you get for completing ALL the quests in the game is about 100kk (100 million). That's not enough to buy you some decent gear. I'm currently trying to get a complete set of 'Palladium of Outrageous' gear, the highest gear in the game with an enchantment on it that amplifies your damage output, one piece of the 4 is 100kk (1 slot) to 1kkk (2 slots), depending on the seller.To grind that amount of money is almost impossible, you'd have to get very good drops to get that amount of Alz. Mot people don't ever bother with that grind and buy Alz instead.- Upgrading, the fastest way to lose your Alz! It can be extremely frustrating to buy an inventory full of Upgrade Core (Highest) (1kk each) and upgrading your +4 item with high hopes, and ending up with a +4 item after you used all cores. It's like this: 4 - 5 - 6 - 7 - 5 - 6 - 7 - 8 - 6 - 7 - 8 - 6 - 5 - 4... bye 50kk!- IGNcode. It's the worst gameguard EVER. My game crashes every 30 mins because of this freaking buggy error. Horrible. (Won't happen to everybody, mostly Windows 8/8.1/10 users.)Although there are those things I don't like, I'll still recommend this game, just play it. It's awesome. :)That's all the pros and cons I can think of right now, if you have any questions about CABAL, or just want to hear some of my stories in the game, feel free to add me! :D

												The game invokes a huge sense of nostalgia within me. Having played this game around 2008/2009, I am glad to see not much has changed - that counts for the bad and good parts though.Essentially, Cabal Online is a game that is very addicting - it is like Diablo or any Lootathon, except that instead of Loot, you are hunting levels. The game is unique in that your EXP and Skill-EXP are separate - using skills and completing some quests fills up your Skill-EXP, and completing quests and killing monsters your normal EXP. Here is a big bad part of the game though - while leveling up is always fun, later skill levels just take way too long to level up and advance. However, it does have an addicting feeling to it, simply because you know that on the next skill level you get even better looking and more powerful skills. I always enjoyed Cabal especially because of the Skill system - powerful Auras, Battle Stances and Skills look great and feel good. The game does have an outdated look, but is still okay to look at - and it just has this unique sense of fun when playing it. It is hard to describe, but it is free, so give it a go!

												I wish I could say something good about this game, as it made up between 5 to 8 years of my life playing in EU's Mars server, but I sort of can't.Despite this being a pretty little mmo that has some flashy graphics, mildly interesting story, and ok pvp (which you can't say about many other mmos), its riddled with problems.Graphics are pretty ok, they look good enough along with the visuals, the sounds are pretty good to be honest, but the game takes a bit hit in the gameplay.People who play the game might convince you otherwise, but the truth is that the only way to be good at the game, is with good gear. Nothing else.Sure there might be a few things you need to know, like tips and tricks for the dungeons, which some might need practice for, but in the end, gear will dictate wether you can do anything at all. Both in PvE and PvP. Especially in PvP.The second, is that if you're rich, you can pretty much buy all your equipment. By buying game store gear with real life money and selling the stuff on the auction house, you can pretty much make a ton of money and buy almost anything you need. I even shamelessly admit I did it myself, because...Problem No.3, and personaly the biggest problem with it, the game is a severe grindfest based PURELY on luck.Remember how I said PvP is very based in gear? Critical hits are dictated by critical hit ratio, and if you have none, you're screwed, and if you have the average (between 45 and 51%) it will pretty much be a "if you crit, you win" situation, which sometimes comes in bags of 9 out of 10, or 2 out of 10. Same goes for enchanting armor, where you'll spend BILLIONS of ingame money to upgrade something ONCE if you're really unlucky, and the same also applies to drops, where you're either lucky enough to enter a dungeon and get a good piece of gear that you can sell (don't fool yourself into thinking you'll easily find good stuff you can wear) or unlucky enough to do the same dungeon 1000 times and never get anything good whatsoever. I've seen it happen, and funny enough, the game has titles for people who go into dungeons that many times.There are also botters, hackers, and gold sellers ingame as usual.The conclusion?Despite a fun little game, its chalk full of problems. You CAN have some fun in it, but after a while, it will most likely get on your nerves.

												It's still a grind fest game, even after 7 years  I played for an hour and a half trying not to fall asleep at my keyboard.Pros Simple leveling system: Quests are pretty much everywhere from lvl 1 to like lvl 90+. Even if you finish all the quests your level, you only need to grind a little bit to reach the next level because the quests give plenty of exp. Skill Combos: All you have to do is put your skills on the skill bar, then the game takes care of the rest. Diverse weapons and armor: There are 3 types of armors, Martial, Armor, and Battle. Martial has highest defense rating/evasion, Armor has highest defense, and Battle is right in between. The look of the armors change drastically as you progress through each set.Cons Skill Grinding: This is the most daunting task. In Cabal, ranking up in skills give you stat boosts as well as hp/mp boosts. And each rank-up stacks, meaning you gain more boosts as you rank up higher and higher. Which also means, in pvp and dungeons, if you do not have high skill ranks, you will get owned big time. I've heard of lvl 90 characters with master skill ranks get owned by a lvl 60 with transcender skill ranks. Drop rates: The drop rates have been drastically reduced. This discouraged many players from playing beyond a certain level, hence why so many players quit. The decrease in drop rate only starts to really get noticeable after you reach 70-80 levels. I have heard countless people complain back when I used to play  non-stop, and I believe the original Cabal (korean) company made this decision. Bots/Gold Sellers/Spammers: Now this is one hell of a major problem in Cabal. There are characters selling gold for real money, bots mindlessly killing mobs in a certain area, and spammers looking to power level people for real money. Crazy Priced Cash Items:  If you saw the prices on the eCoins and cash shop items, you would have had quite a shock. To receive a 30-day premium, you need to pay roughly $18-20. Now what would you prefer? pay $5 bucks or so extra to play a game where the staff/admins barely even put up an effort to improve their merchandise.

												Ok so, I used to play this game in the past and enjoyed it a whole lot back then, and even if I'm gonna try to be as fair as possible in this, do take my words with a grain of nostalgia salt. (also tl;dr version further below)The game has aged surprisingly well with the graphics being maybe not that great, but not horrid either; the combat is pretty straightforward and it has a pretty interesting skill leveling system where you build up skill experience to achieve new a new rank and acquire new skills or the ability to strengthen old ones. Classes are interesting and the skills that you can get on the higher levels often look pretty cool. Dungeons can be pretty fun to do with friends and especially from he halfway point onwards (which is level 100) dungeons can get pretty intreguing with puzzle-like bits. As you may have guessed from an old game there is a lot of grinding to be had, though the premium you get with a new account makes this a whole lot easier and quicker. (I'm not sure if the premium is gonna be for every new account or just as a one-time thing because it went over to steam)That however, is where the good points kind of end with the game; grinding is very much a problem once your premium runs out, as you will have to walk everywhere and lose the ability to teleport around the maps; as well as losing a lot of inventory space. At the higher levels you can also run into money problems, as quests stop giving money for some reason and leveling passive skills becomes really expensive. Even with the blessing beads you're given with every new character (gives +200% exp for a month) the grind just becomes a chore. The game also has a lack of variety in armor, having only 3 types of armor and every new tier of armor basically looks the same but with a different color or slight changes (until you start reaching the level 130+ gear). The weapons are okay mind you, but other than for stat purposes I never found myself looking forward to getting new gear. Questing is dull and repeatitive as all quests basically fall into the category of kill things, loot things, talk to things or re-enter this place you just left... things.Now I know that all things I spoke of are PvE related, but that's the point; even if I'm not a fan of PvP anyway, it takes a lot of grinding to get to the point where you can join PvP events (random dueling aside), let alone stand a chance because everyone and their mom is likely level 200 in there and can one-shot you. (do note I'm not sure about that as I never indulged in pvp with the steam version, but if I'm to believe how it was back in the day, that's how it goes.)Sooo tl;dr. (for PVE things)Pros:Aged okay in terms of graphics.Interesting classes/skill leveling system.Interesting dungeons.Free premium at the start(?).Cons:Game becomes a whole lot worse once premium runs out. (not kidding it really breaks the game)Design of gear is rather stale. (weapons are decent though)Questing is very dull. (and the main way to level up)What I recommend with this game is give it a shot (preferably with friends); and if you find it to be fun, play it until the free premium runs out (if that's not a limited event thing). If you can look past all the things you lose after that, good for you, but I wouldn't recommend investing in new premium unless you really really like this game. If a game deliberately becomes horrible without premium I wouldn't support it, but that may just be me.

												I binged this game back when access to Port Lux was an achievement.There has been MAJOR improvement to this game since then and it honestly ease some pain off for players, both old and new.One being the removal of leveling SWORD spell and MAGIC spell seperately.Back then, each Sword based spell you cast only gives you sword exp and vice versa. You have to pay a large sum of cash to a particular instructor to temporary learn the ability to convert Sword exp to Magic exp.  The only way to evenly level them is to literally punch enemies for HOURS. Your spells are not restricted to your level like most mmorpg, you can be very VERY low leveled and have punch your way to access the highest spell possible (to those who play WoW, this is Cabal version of a Twink) and absolutely annihilate people in duels.Pro :-Flashiest and most unique skills in all MMORPG I've ever played-Most unique class variant -Easy to learn rotation to maximize DPS/survivalbility-Forum is rich with topics to help you learn your class. Knowledge is power.-The most beautiful design of swords and armor. (For the lads, most steamiest armors for female characters)Subjective (some people have zero problem with this compared to me) :-Traveling to dungeons is somewhat off putting due to the distance (unless you have a hoverboard /bike )-Limited bag space unless premium player (Think Diablo 2 /Path Of Exile level of bag space)-Your skill =/= your level, you do not gain new spells base on level , but base on proficient . You will definitely be leaving your character AFK-ing at the Training Dummy to gain the SKILL exp to be able to learn the new spell (Think of it as Ragnarok 1 ,where you have a Base Level and Job Level). This really isn’t a problem unless you are concern about your PC/Laptop overheating if you log in to park your character at the training dummy to go out to do something.-Certain class may seem over/underpowered at certain level bracket but they all simmer down to being "Eh"-Winning the Nation War does actually matter to an extend. When the faction you choose wins the War, premium players are granted access to warp points shortcuts which lets them transverse to dungeon much quicker and faster.-One particular class, the Force Shielder, is very versatile. You can be the standard DPSer (add more str), A tank (Add more dex) or a Magic user! (add more Int)Con :-When you reach roughly lvl 50 (I think) you are somewhat forced to choose a Faction (Alliance vs Horde, Exile vs Dominion yada yada yada) If you maintain neutral, both factions will be able to attack you. It will almost always be a 3 faction combat. (Your chosen Faction) vs (Enemy faction + Neutral Faction) . When you reach that point in the game, it's all open PVP from here (as far as I know). Certain dungeons are located in said dangerous zone,so be prepared to be ganked from the bushes when you are on your way.-Pay2SaveTime but not Pay2Win much. The Cash Shop (Microtransaction) lets you buy the materials that you need to upgrade your gears with, nothing you can't get with a little diligence. You and I will get the same identical gear in end game, just that whoever forks out the cash gets it soon, THAT IS ALL. I’M LOOKING AT YOU MAPLESTORY!!-There is somewhat of a grind after lvl 100 onward, but there are dailies that you can do to rake in a few exp and money from.-Tutorial is mandatory if you wanna proceed , can be a drag when you want to level an alt.-A small portion of your money will be used regardless to buy spells, had you been doing quest, this really shouldn’t be an issue.These are all the pro and con I can think off from my experience.I know it seems that there is a wall of text for con, but it is solely to justify it, so don't get too offput by it!

												I used to play this game a lot, back when skill XP and character level XP were still very separate.This game is pretty basic. If you're not interested in PVP there's not much to do beyond run around and kill samey enemies. But I really like the overall aesthetic that it has going. The crystalline "astral weapons" are really cool, and attack animations are crazy over the top!There are some cute mechanics spread throughout this game. Force Blader's "battle mode" transforms their magic spells into buffs, allowing for cool customization. You can equip the armor of any class even if it isn't meant for your own class, as long as you can meet its requirements. Although (sort of) recent changes have shrunken build diversity.And the "COMBO" system is really amazing! never seen it in another MMORPG. Once you hit level 30, you get a special power that can lower the casting time on all of your skills as long as you can keep up the tight timing!Main downsides for this game are the sheer repitition (nothing for PvE-minded players but repetitive grind), small community, and BOTS. But I don't think you can expect much more from a MMORPG of this age. If you do decide to try this, do NOT get the version on steam! Download client from ESTsoft, and play on the Titan server! Atlas has very low population, and is the only server available from steam client!
